text: Blessed be he that cometh in the name of the LORD: we have blessed you out of the house of the LORD.
text_kjv: Blessed be he that cometh in the name of the LORD: we have blessed you out of the house of the LORD.
text_niv: Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord.From the house of the Lord we bless you.
text_esv: Blessed is he who comes in the name of the LORD! We bless you from the house of the LORD.

text_nasb: Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the LORD; We have blessed you from the house of the LORD.
context: Psalm 118 is a Hallel psalm, likely sung during major Jewish festivals like Passover, Sukkot (Feast of Tabernacles), and Shavuot (Pentecost). It's a song of thanksgiving, celebrating God's enduring steadfast love and deliverance. The psalm depicts a triumphal entry, possibly alluding to a king returning from battle or a priest leading a procession. The phrase 'the gate of the LORD' (verse 20) suggests a physical location, likely the Temple gates in Jerusalem. The 'house of the LORD' signifies the Temple itself, the center of Jewish worship and God's dwelling place. The blessing spoken here wasn't just an ordinary greeting. It was a formal, liturgical pronouncement, imbued with religious significance. Understanding the historical context of pilgrimage festivals is crucial. During these times, large crowds would journey to Jerusalem, creating a heightened sense of anticipation and celebration. The Temple priests and Levites played a vital role in leading worship and offering blessings to those entering the sacred space. Recognizing this setting helps us grasp the celebratory and prophetic nature of this verse.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 118:26 holds profound significance, especially in light of the New Testament. The phrase 'Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord' is directly quoted in the Gospels (Matthew 21:9, Mark 11:9, Luke 19:38, John 12:13) during Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem. This quotation immediately identifies Jesus as the Messiah, the one sent by God to bring salvation. The 'he who comes' refers to the anticipated Messiah, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies. The fact that this verse was used to acclaim Jesus as King reveals the prophetic nature of the psalm. 'Coming in the name of the Lord' signifies acting with God's authority and representing His will. It suggests divine delegation and power. The blessing originating 'out of the house of the Lord' implies that the authority to bless comes from God Himself, mediated through the Temple and its representatives (initially). Furthermore, the 'house of the Lord' foreshadows the church, where believers are blessed in Christ's name. The passage also highlights the enduring covenant love of God and his faithfulness to his people, promising to send the Messiah and bless those who welcome him.
application: In our modern context, Psalm 118:26 calls us to recognize and welcome Jesus as the Messiah, not just in a historical sense, but in our daily lives. We should actively seek His presence and allow Him to reign in our hearts. How often do we truly recognize the opportunities we have to bless others in the name of the Lord? This verse encourages us to be intentional about speaking blessings and encouragement into the lives of those around us. We can do this through our words, actions, and prayers. Consider your sphere of influence - your family, friends, workplace, and community. In what specific ways can you extend the blessing of God's love and grace to them? Furthermore, reflecting on the 'house of the Lord' which, now in our age, is the body of believers (the Church), we should consider how we contribute to a welcoming and blessing-filled community. Are we creating a space where others can experience God's love and acceptance? Are we actively participating in blessing and serving others within the church? This can involve volunteering, offering support, or simply showing genuine care and concern. It's about being a conduit of God's blessing to a world desperately in need of hope and healing. We need to recognize that, like the initial Temple setting, the blessing is not simply a nice sentiment; it's a declaration of God's favor and presence, empowered by our faith.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for sending your Son, Jesus, who came in your name to redeem us. Help us to recognize Him daily in our lives and to welcome Him with open hearts. Fill us with your Holy Spirit, so that we may be instruments of your blessing to those around us. Give us the courage and wisdom to speak words of encouragement and to act in ways that reflect your love and grace. May our lives be a testament to your enduring faithfulness and may we be a part of your loving and supportive Church, a place of healing and blessing for all. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.
